questions.title: 1. My best ideas at work come from
selections: an interchange of ideas and sharing with others.
quiet thought on my own.

questions.title: 2. When I run a meeting, I am usually
selections: disciplined about following my prepared agenda.
flexible and open to whatever comes up.

questions.title: 3. When handling a subordinate's development, I am most likely to
selections: discuss a problem I have with his or her behavior.
dislike telling him or her unpleasant things.

questions.title: 4. I prefer the place I work to be
selections: structured with clear rules and regulations.
more open-ended and laissez-faire.

questions.title: 5. I would rather have a supervisor with whom I have
selections: a lot of day-by-day interaction.
only infrequent interaction.

questions.title: 6. I prefer meetings where most time is spent on
selections: the application of the ideas discussed.
the ideas themselves.

questions.title: 7. I prefer a work environment where
selections: frequent differences of opinion breed interesting discussions and ideas.
conflict is reduced by avoiding discussions about differences of opinion.

questions.title: 8. I prefer projects at work
selections: to be well-defined and planned out.
to allow for flexible interpretation.

questions.title: 9. I prefer to spend my lunch hour
selections: eating with a group.
eating alone or with one close colleague.

questions.title: 10. If my boss gives me a difficult task, I usually
selections: collect as much information as possible before starting.
dive in and rely on my ability to work things out.

questions.title: 11. In a performance appraisal, I prefer my boss to write that I am
selections: intelligent and reasonable.
warm and personable.

questions.title: 12. I prefer to
selections: plan my workday carefully in advance.
let the day progress and see how things turn out.

questions.title: 13. I more often prefer to keep my office door
selections: open.
closed.

questions.title: 14. When a new idea flashes into my mind, I usually
selections: like to test if carefully before I get excited.
get excited and want to follow through quickly.

questions.title: 15. In a team meeting, I prefer to emphasize
selections: an analytical discussion of the facts.
a discussion of the values involved.

questions.title: 16. I prefer a job in which the rewards are
selections: seen clearly in regular periods.
stretched out over long periods of time.

questions.title: 17. I dress for work
selections: so that other people notice and admire my clothing.
in a way that blends in with the norm.

questions.title: 18. When I solve problems, I am more likely to
selections: give most weight to the facts in front of me.
explore the full range of possibilities.

questions.title: 19. If I have to confront colleagues or subordinates, I am usually
selections: interested in making sure I give them the facts accurately.
more interested in making sure I don't hurt their feelings.

questions.title: 20. I would rather have a boss who
selections: provides a lot of structure and organization.
leaves me to do things however they work best for me.

questions.title: 21. I prefer most of my jobs at work to be
selections: a continuing series of short tasks.
long projects on which I can concentrate my efforts.

questions.title: 22. When I write a report, I usually think first of
selections: the details.
the big picture.

questions.title: 23. When I have a decision to make at work, I usually
selections: reason it through regardless of my feelings.
consider my feelings to be very important.

questions.title: 24. I prefer my own office to be one in which
selections: things are olderly, organized, and systematic.
there is a creative array of projects, papers, and books.

questions.title: 25. When I have lunch with my colleagues, I would rather
selections: talk about people.
talk about ideas.

questions.title: 26. I would rather have my boss trust me with
selections: practical problems to solve.
policy problems to solve.

questions.title: 27. When faced with a decision at work, I usually prefer to
selections: think things through.
trust my gut feelings.

questions.title: 28. I prefer the work I do every day to
selections: be continuous and relatively predictable.
have frequent changes in activities and schedules.

questions.title: 29. When I have to organize and run a meeting, I more often
selections: feel satisfied that I have the opportunity to lead.
prefer that someone else had the responsibility.

questions.title: 30. If I were asked to prepare a strategic plan, I would be more likely to
selections: emphasize what is practical now.
orient the plan toward future possibilities.

questions.title: 31. When faced with a decision at work, I usually
selections: focus on the facts and figures above all.
give careful attention to people's feelings.

questions.title: 32. When my boss gives me a new project, I usually prefer
selections: a clear statement of what is expected.
to be left to work it out the way I want.

questions.title: 33. I prefer to have
selections: a large group of colleagues at work.
a few colleagues that I know well.

questions.title: 34. In one-on-one meetings, I am more likely to
selections: listen quietly and absorb details.
anticipate the speaker's words and interject.

questions.title: 35. If someone argues with a policy or decision I make, I usually
selections: remain firm.
seek to avoid unpleasantness, anger, and disharmony.

questions.title: 36. When I have made a tough choice at work, I usually
selections: am satisfied that it is done.
wish that I could remain open to other alternatives.

questions.title: 37. When I attend a company outing, I usually
selections: walk around and meet people I may not know well.
hang out with the colleagues I know best.

questions.title: 38. I think my colleagues see me more
selections: as a here-and-now person.
as someone with an orientation toward the future.

questions.title: 39. When I have a long and complex report to read, I am more likely to
selections: be patient and study the details.
try to get the general ideas and see how I feel about them.

questions.title: 40. I prefer my work environment to be
selections: comfortable, predictable, and stable.
flexible and changing.

questions.title: 41. My colleagues at work are more likely to describe me as
selections: an energetic team player.
a quiet and thoughtful employee.

questions.title: 42. When I prepare a presentation, I prefer to emphasize
selections: the use of real facts from my own experience.
the discussion of ideas and concepts.

questions.title: 43. I prefer to work with colleagues who
selections: rely heavily on logic.
look more often to their feelings.

questions.title: 44. If someone on my team is late with a scheduled task, I usually
selections: get impatient and annoyed.
look for ways to stretch the deadlines.

questions.title: 45. When I attend a training session, I am more likely to
selections: participate openly and actively.
let others take the active role.

questions.title: 46. When colleagues and subordinates present ideas to me, I am usually more interested in
selections: immediately useful ideas.
ideas with innovative approaches.

questions.title: 47. If I have to deal with a colleague's feelings, I prefer to be
selections: truthful even if I can't be tactful.
tactful, even if I can't tell the truth.

questions.title: 48. I prefer projects that
selections: have a clear ending date when I know they will be finished.
may remain open-ended to ensure that all bases are covered.

questions.title: 49. When I have a decision to make at work, I more often
selections: talk it over with a number of people before I decide.
spend most of my time working it out in my own head.

questions.title: 50. I prefer a job where I can
selections: use my experience to work at familiar tasks.
confront ideas and problems that are new to me.

questions.title: 51. When I am at a meeting and a difference of opinion gets heated, I usually
selections: defend the side I think is most logical.
try to create a harmonious atmosphere and solution.

questions.title: 52. When I get a new project, I usually prefer to
selections: get to it and complete it as quickly as possible.
move as slowly as allowable and explore various approaches.

questions.title: 53. I am more interested in
selections: the actual tasks I am doing day-by-day.
the thoughts I have about my work.

questions.title: 54. When I attend a training session, I usually prefer
selections: experiential processes.
information and abstractions.

questions.title: 55. When I have a meeting with a colleague, I usually
selections: get through it quickly in a businesslike manner.
linger over the sociable interaction.

questions.title: 56. I would rather be in a job with
selections: activities requiring me to reach a conclusion.
activities that allow me to stay open to my experience.

questions.title: 57. When I ask a colleague for advice or help, I am usually
selections: comfortable.
somewhat ill at ease.

questions.title: 58. In a meeting or when reading a report, I am more likely to
selections: remember the facts presented.
remember mostly the concepts presented.

questions.title: 59. When colleagues ask my advice about a work matter, I more often
selections: guide them toward a decision based purely on logic.
help them explore the values and policies in the situation.

questions.title: 60. When I am in a meeting, I am usually more interested in
selections: getting the job done as quickly as possible.
spending time making sure everyone gets heard.

questions.title: 61. When I am interrupted in the middle of a tough job, I usually
selections: welcome the opportunity to talk to someone.
prefer to be left alone with my thoughts.

questions.title: 62. When I read a report, I usually go first to
selections: the body of detailed information.
the summary or executive overview.

questions.title: 63. When I am putting forward a new idea at work, I more often
selections: remain firm about the correctness of it.
try to persuade others by appealing to their sense of value.

questions.title: 64. If my boss insists that I schedule my workday, I feel
selections: satisfied I am organized.
uncomfortable that I am constrained.

questions.title: 65. When I am at a meeting and someone tells a joke, I usually
selections: laugh and think of one to tell.
enjoy the joke quietly.

questions.title: 66. In a performance appraisal, it would be more accurate if my boss said I was
selections: practical.
imaginative.

questions.title: 67. I am usually more interested in how my colleagues
selections: think about problems.
feel about problems.

questions.title: 68. When a new and unusual policy announcement is issued at work, I am usually
selections: annoyed or otherwise upset at the changes.
interested in seeing how I will handle the new environment.

questions.title: 69. In a meeting, I usually
selections: speak out directly when I want to.
wait until I am asked directly before I speak.

questions.title: 70. When I start a new project, I usually
selections: write a step-by-step plan early in the process.
wait and see how things develop before planning.

questions.title: 71. When I hear a presentation from a colleague, I am more likely to be
selections: openly and intellectually critical.
careful in voicing my opinions, especially when I disagree.

questions.title: 72. If they couldn't be both, I would rather have colleagues who are
selections: well-organized.
spontaneous.

questions.title: 73. I would prefer to work in a company where
selections: everyone works together in an open, active environment.
people work independently in their own spaces.

questions.title: 74. I more often seek out work that applies
selections: my practical skills and nature.
my ability to create new ideas and things.

questions.title: 75. When I have to make a decision at work, I am more likely to
selections: analyze the situation logically without considering my values and feelings.
put a strong emphasis on applying my values and feelings to the solution.

questions.title: 76. When I present my views in a meeting, I am usually
selections: decisive.
open to having others suggest changes and other views.

questions.title: 77. When I need to pass on an idea or information, I prefer to
selections: talk directly to people about it.
put it in writing.

questions.title: 78. My leadership style is best described as
selections: practical.
visionary.

questions.title: 79. In a performance appraisal meeting, I am usually more likely to
selections: be frank and honest regardless of feelings.
try to smooth over any problems and avoid hurt feelings.

questions.title: 80. When I am discussing an important issue at a meeting, I usually
selections: try to reach a definite conclusion quickly.
keep the options open.

questions.title: 81. I enjoy more
selections: a workday filled with variety and interactions with others.
working without interacting with others for long periods of time.

questions.title: 82. I prefer a work situation that is
selections: stable with little change.
full of change.

questions.title: 83. My colleagues would be more likely to describe my behavior at work as
selections: cool, calm, and objective.
warm and feeling.

questions.title: 84. At work, I prefer projects
selections: on which I work quickly to make a short deadline.
that have longer and more flexible deadlines.

questions.title: 85. When I am in a meeting with colleagues and a high-ranking manager or executive comes in, I usually
selections: greet the person in a comfortable and friendly way.
wait until I see how others react to him or her.

questions.title: 86. When I think of my most important work assets, they are
selections: more in the realm of the practical.
more inclined toward the realm of ideas.

questions.title: 87. In a training session or course, I prefer a trainer who depends more on
selections: precision and logic.
emotion and experience.

questions.title: 88. I usually push my colleagues or subordinates for
selections: quick decisions.
thorough review, even at the risk of delaying decisions.
